title: Historical Stock Splits and Corporate Actions of Under Armour Inc

content.text: Under Armour Inc goes public and starts trading on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol 'UAA'.
Under Armour Inc executes a 2-for-1 stock split. Shareholders receive one additional share for every share held, effectively doubling the number of shares outstanding.
Under Armour Inc announces a 2-for-1 stock split. Shareholders receive one additional share for every share held, resulting in a doubling of shares outstanding.
Under Armour Inc declares a 2-for-1 stock split. Shareholders receive one additional share for every share held, leading to a doubling of shares outstanding.
Under Armour Inc implements a 2-for-1 stock split. Shareholders receive one additional share for every share held, effectively doubling the number of shares outstanding.
Under Armour Inc undergoes a 1-for-4 reverse stock split. Shareholders receive one share for every four shares held, resulting in a reduction in shares outstanding.
Under Armour Inc announces a 3-for-1 stock split. Shareholders are set to receive two additional shares for every share held, which will triple the number of shares outstanding.
No significant stock splits or corporate actions announced for Under Armour Inc as of the current year.

news.headline: Lululemon is a buy despite these investor concerns: Analyst
news.summary: The athletic apparel and footwear industry has been underperforming throughout 2024. CFRA analyst Zachary Warring joins Market Domination to discuss his outlook on the athleisure space. Warring attributes the sector's challenges to macroeconomic headwinds and weakening consumer spending. However, he notes, "there are some companies that have been able to grow through this." He identifies Lululemon (LULU) and Nike (NKE) as retail names currently presenting good buying opportunities, despite the consumer slowdown affecting their multiples. He stresses that these brands still have growth potential. Addressing competition concerns, particularly for Lululemon, Warring tells Yahoo Finance: "I think investors have gotten a little bit scared thinking that they might not grow anymore, but estimates are still at 10 to 11% this year in terms of revenue... so it's not like you're seeing a decline." For more expert insight and the latest market action, click here to watch this full episode of Market Domination. This post was written by Angel Smith

news.headline: Mortgage rates, Lumen CEO, Good Buy or Goodbye: Market Domination
news.summary: Stock market indexes (^DJI, ^IXIC, ^GSPC) and sectors are holding steady in positive territory ahead of Thursday's market close. Julie Hyman and Josh Lipton provide coverage of the top industry stories and interview economists, market strategists, and CEOs in the final trading hour of the day. Lumen Technologies (LUMN) CEO Kate Johnson sits down with the Market Domination team in-studio to discuss the telecommunications provider's AI partnerships with various mega-cap tech companies. Summit Global Investments CIO Dave Harden joins the program for its latest installment of Good Buy or Goodbye to talk about which Magnificent Seven tech name he is seeing opportunities in and which other he is avoiding. Other top trending tickers on the Yahoo Finance platform include Under Armour (UAA, UA), Zillow Group (Z, ZG), McKesson Corporation (MCK), and Monster Beverage Corp. (MNST). This post was written by Luke Carberry Mogan.

news.headline: Under Armour moves higher on Q1 beat, full-year guidance lift
news.summary: Under Armour (UAA, UA) soars even higher in Thursday trading ahead of the closing bell after beating fiscal first quarter estimates, posting revenue of $1.18 billion ($1.14 billion expected) and adjusted earnings of $0.01 per share (a loss of $0.04 per share was expected). The Market Domination team examines the athletic wear brand's first quarter print as it lifts its full-year guidance and CEO Kevin Plank's cost-cutting approaches taking aim now at discounting. For more expert insight and the latest market action, click here to watch this full episode of Market Domination. This post was written by Luke Carberry Mogan.

news.headline: Jobless claims data, WBD stock falls further: Morning Brief
news.summary: The US equity market (^DJI, ^IXIC, ^GSPC) and bitcoin (BTC-USD) in the crypto space both aim to start the trading day off right, bouncing back from this week's sell-off. Morning Brief hosts Seana Smith and Brad Smith monitor market activity while tracking the top industry stories and moving stocks. Stifel chief economist and managing director Lindsey Piegza joins the program to discuss whether recent US employment data could be enough to sway the Federal Reserve to initiate interest rate cuts. Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD) shares move lower this morning after the media company missed on second quarter revenue estimates and wrote down its linear TV assets in a $9.1 billion impairment charge. MoffettNathanson senior research analyst Robert Fishman highlights how WBD's troubles with possibly losing NBA streaming rights could hurt their affiliate fee revenues. Other top trending tickers on the Yahoo Finance platform include Boeing (BA), Under Armour (UA, UAA), and Nvidia (NVDA) This post was written by Luke Carberry Mogan.

news.headline: Under Armour (UAA) Stock Trades Up, Here Is Why
news.summary: Shares of athletic apparel company Under Armour (NYSE:UAA) jumped 19.6% in the afternoon session after the company reported second-quarter earnings results. Under Armour blew past analysts' constant currency revenue expectations. Its EPS also outperformed Wall Street's estimates. Moving on, full year EPS guidance was above expectations, which was icing on the cake. Zooming out, we think this was certainly a solid quarter.

news.headline: Under Armour Stock Pops After Earnings. Leadership Shuffle Sees Positive Early Returns.
news.summary: Founder Kevin Plank took the reins from former CEO Stephanie Linnartz in April, and the company has since been in refresh mode.

news.headline: Under Armour stock soars on Q1 results
news.summary: Shares of Under Armour (UA, UAA) are jumping in early trading. The athletic apparel company reported first quarter results that topped Wall Street estimates on both the top and bottom lines. The company is undergoing a turnaround effort, with newly reinstated CEO Kevin Plank saying in the release that leadership is "encouraged by early progress in our efforts to reconstitute a premium positioning for the Under Armour brand." Morning Brief anchors Seana Smith and Brad Smith recap Under Armour's results in the video above. For more expert insight and the latest market action, click here to watch this full episode of Morning Brief. This post was written by Stephanie Mikulich.

news.headline: Under Armour Stock Jumps on Sportwear Brand's Surprise Profit
news.summary: Under Armour shares rallied after the apparel maker posted a surprise quarterly adjusted profit, despite slumping sales.  The stock opened up 13% at $7.06 and edged higher from there.  The sportswear brand said Thursday that excluding $308 million in one-time charges, including litigation expenses and costs related to a restructuring, it generated a $4 million adjusted profit last quarter.  Analysts had expected an adjusted loss, as the company executes its turnaround plan.

news.headline: Under Armour (NYSE:UAA) Reports Upbeat Q2, Stock Jumps 11.4%
news.summary: Athletic apparel company Under Armour (NYSE:UAA) beat analysts' expectations in Q2 CY2024, with revenue down 10.1% year on year to $1.18 billion. It made a non-GAAP profit of $0.18 per share, improving from its profit of $0.02 per share in the same quarter last year.

news.summary: The Baltimore-based company posted an operating loss of $300 million on a 10 percent sales drop in the first fiscal quarter.

news.headline: Under Armour posts surprise profit on higher margins, leaner inventory
news.summary: (Reuters) -Under Armour posted a surprise first-quarter profit on Thursday on margins boost from selling its sports apparel at full price and lower inventory at a time when consumers get picky with what they spend their dollars on.  Its shares surged 18% in early trading as the company also raised its annual profit forecast.  As a result, gross margins expanded 110 basis points to 47.5% and inventory dropped 15% to $1.1 billion.

news.headline: UNDER ARMOUR ANNOUNCES ERIC LIEDTKE AS EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT OF BRAND STRATEGY
news.summary: Under Armour, Inc. (NYSE: UA, UAA) today announced that Eric Liedtke will join the company as Executive Vice President of Brand Strategy following the completion of its acquisition of UNLESS COLLECTIVE, INC (UNLESS), a zero-plastic regenerative fashion brand. The transaction is expected to be completed later this week.

news.headline: Under Armour chief consumer officer exits as 26-year Adidas veteran joins the brand
news.summary: Jim Dausch is leaving at the end of the month as Eric Liedtke, former brand president at Adidas, joins the company to lead brand strategy.
